metadata.title: X575: writing rengas with web services

sections.text: Our software system simulates the classic Japanese collaborative form of poetry, Renga, from linked haiku. We used NLP methods packaged as web services. Our experiments were only a partial success, as the results do not meet classical limitations. To gather ideas for future work, we investigate related research in semiotics, linguistics, and computer science.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, the haikus are a carefully composed juxtaposition of two concepts used by Ventura (2016) as the starting point for a thought experiment at the level of computer-aided creativity, with creative levels ranging from randomization to plagiarization, generalization, and creation, and other gradations and criteria that could be advanced, such as the fitness function used for filtration.

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that we will be able to set out to find a solution that is in the position in which we find ourselves.

sections.heading: 3 Example
sections.text: Here is a haiku that our system has written in response to the two prompts "frog pond" and "moon." Most of the haikus in the system are not so clever or thematic: the probability of finding one of these characteristics is at least 100 / 1. Seagull in dress - vivid in the statue of so many ebbs and flows

sections.heading: 4 Implementation
sections.text: In collaboration with a small haiku corpus, we used a POS tagger to reveal the grammatical structure typical of haikus. The CMU pronouncing dictionary is used to count syllables of words that fill this structure.4 Wikipedia provides a generic text corpus that we used to generate n grammars, with more frequent constructions in haikus.5 The Wikipedia data was also processed with GloVe (Pennington et al., 2014) to create a semantic vector space model of topics based on word collisions. 6 In short: 1. Haiku corpus → POS tagger → grammatical skeleton fragments. 2. General text corpus → n grammar model. 3. General text corpus → theme vectors. 4. Combine skeleton fragments to make aikhau template 5. syllable slots.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion and Related Work
sections.text: Towards automated evaluation Some of the evaluation dimensions are built into the way the poems are constructed. As mentioned above, form is explicitly considered for haikus. To a certain extent are also sense and thema.Sense: we have a n-gram model of text probability, which gives a higher score for constructions that are frequently observed phrases.Topic: we have a vector model of the subject word (s), and can determine the distance to the vector given by the sum of words in the poem. Results could certainly be improved in this regard: further, compared to a single haiku, our rengas ask for a much more interpolation of meaning on the reader's side. Questions with form re-emerge here: our generated rengas does not meet the classical constraints. Results should be with the addition of "audio equaliser style" parameters such as priority, dither and saturation.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In terms of Ventura's hierarchy of creative levels, the haiku system seems to be in the "generalization phase." Our Renga writing experiments with FloWr brought with them a "filtration aspect." The research topics discussed above point to a direction for future work in terms of the stages of "foundation" and "creativity."
